questions.text: A woman is presented to ENT OPD with complaints of nasal obstruction O/E greenish black crust seen in nasal cavity covering turbinate & septum. She also had merciful anosmia. What other sign will you find in this case on examination
questions.solution:
In Atrophic rhinitis, Examination shows nasal cavity to be full of greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates so much so that the posterior wall of nasopharynx can be easily seen.

Option B: Nasal polyps are soft, non-calcified growth usually arising from the prolapsed mucosa and are not associated by roomy nose.

Option C: Foreign body in the nasal cavity can cause nasal obstruction and foul smelling nasal discharge but does not cause characteristic greenish black crusting and roomy nose.

Option D: Inferior turbinate hypertrophy refers to the enlargement of the inferior turbinate which can cause nasal obstruction.

questions.text: Patient with history of chronic middle ear infection now presents with neurological manifestations headache & vomiting CT brain is shown probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given image in the question shows the CT scan showing otogenic brain abscess. Neurological manifestations, headache and vomiting in a patient history of chronic middle ear infection suggest intracranial complications such as temporal lobe abscess.

Option A: Extradural abscess: It is collection of pus between the bone and dura. It may occur both in acute and chronic infections of middle ear.

Option B: Cerebral abscess: It usually presents with the complain of ear discharge associated with the Spontaneous nystagmus, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral hypotonia and weakness, past pointing and intentional tremor.

Option D: Meningitis: It is inflammation of leptomeninges (pia and arachnoid) usually with bacterial invasion of CSF in subarachnoid space. It is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media. It can occur in both acute and chronic otitis media. In infants and children, otogenic meningitis usually follows acute otitis media while in adults it is due to chronic middle ear infection.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presents with epistaxis conservative management was done to stop the bleeding but it failed which will be the next step of management
questions.solution:
Endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (ESPAL) is an effective intervention for severe or refractory epistaxis when conservative management fails. It involves the ligation of the sphenopalatine artery, which is the main source of blood supply to the anterior nasal septum.

Other options:

B. Maxillary artery: While the maxillary artery is the source of blood supply to the sphenopalatine artery, ligating the maxillary artery is an extensive and invasive procedure not typically performed for epistaxis.

C. ICA (Internal Carotid Artery): The internal carotid artery is a major blood vessel supplying the brain.

D. ECA (External Carotid Artery): This artery supplies blood to the face and scalp. It is not as likely to be the source of epistaxis.

questions.text: A patient of thyroidectomy was being extubated the anaesthesiologist realized that when he removes the tube the patients being to have recurrent cyanotic spells which of the following could be the cause
questions.solution:
Bilateral Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Palsy- In such cases only muscle which is working is cricothyroid which is supplied by external branch of superior laryngeal artery whose function is adduction.It can lead to vocal cord paralysis and bilateral vocal cord immobility. In such cases, when the endotracheal tube is removed, the vocal cords cannot abduct resulting in recurrent cyanotic spells.

Other options and brief explanations:

B. B/L SLN Palsy (Bilateral Superior Laryngeal Nerve Palsy): Bilateral Superior Laryngeal Nerve Palsy does not cause vocal cord paralysis, and it would not result in the described recurrent cyanotic spells.

C. Edema: While post-thyroidectomy edema can cause airway compromise, it would not lead to recurrent cyanotic spells upon extubation.

D. Hemorrhage: Hemorrhage can be a complication after thyroidectomy but would not directly cause recurrent cyanotic spells upon extubation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the topical use of the medicine shown in the image
questions.solution:
The drug shown in the image is Mitomycin C, and it is used topically for the treatment of subglottic stenosis. Subglottic stenosis is a condition where the airway just below the vocal cords becomes narrow, leading to breathing difficulties. Mitomycin C is applied topically during endoscopic procedures to help prevent the recurrence of scar tissue formation and reduce the narrowing of the airway in cases of subglottic stenosis. It is also used to prevent synchiae formation after nasal surgeries.

Other options:

B. Inlay type 1 myringoplasty: Mitomycin C is not used topically for myringoplasty procedures. Myringoplasty is a surgical technique to repair a perforated eardrum.

C. Post adenoidectomy to control bleeding: Mitomycin C is not commonly used topically for controlling bleeding post-adenoidectomy. Hemostatic techniques and packing are more commonly used for this purpose.

D. Rhino-cerebral mucormycosis: While Mitomycin C is an antifungal agent, it is not typically used topically for the treatment of rhino-cerebral mucormycosis. Systemic antifungal medications are the primary treatment for this severe fungal infection.

choices.text: Take to OT and remove the clot and re-ligation
Take to OT and pressure packing

questions.text: A post tonsillectomy child was lying in the ward he started bleeding in the ward which of the following should be done
questions.solution: Take to OT, remove the clot and re-ligation: In the given question as the hemorrhage occurs within a period of 24hrs known as Reactionary hemorrhage which can be controlled by simple measures like removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Presence of the clot prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle on the vessels which pass through it. If above measures fail, ligation or electro-coagualtion of the bleeding vessels can be done under general anaesthesia.

questions.text: A patient had undergone submandibular gland excision and the wharton's duct was ligated in the process. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3). It provides sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. During submandibular gland excision, the lingual nerve can be at risk of injury because it passes close to the gland leading to numbness or altered sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Other options and brief explanations:

A. Inferior alveolar nerve: This nerve supplies sensation to the lower teeth and

gums. It is not as likely to be damaged during submandibular gland excision as the lingual nerve.

B. Hypoglossal nerve: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates the muscles of the tongue and is not at risk during submandibular gland excision.

D. Nerve to mylohyoid: The nerve to mylohyoid is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (CN V3) and supplies the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric muscles, but it is not at risk during submandibular gland excision.

KEY TAKEAWAY- 3 nerves are in danger while submandibular gland excision.

  1. Marginal mandibular nerve - supplies skin of the angle of mouth.
  2. Hypoglossal nerve - supplies tongue muscle
  3. Lingual nerve - sensory supply to the anterior 2/3rd of tongue.

questions.text: A child was brought by a mother with a history of dysphagia. On inquiry she informed that the child was playing alone & gave a history of foreign body ingestion. X-ray was done & images are given. What is the most likely site of foreign body
questions.solution:
The given image shows PA View: A radio opaque foreign body (coin) in the Esophagus at the level of thoracic inlet and Lateral view neck showing a foreign body (coin) like a slit in the esophagus.

Option A: Trachea: If the foreign body was in trachea it would have caused choking and respiratory distress and not dysphagia. Here radiopaque foreign body (coin) seen in lateral view and slit in AP view.

Option B: If the foreign body was in larynx it would have caused respiratory distress along with coughing and stridor.

Option D: Bronchus: If the foreign body was in the bronchus it would have caused symptoms like breathlessness, stridor, coughing and signs like decreased breath sounds.

questions.text: A patient was admitted with skull base trauma. The doctor was testing the movements of the marked structure. Which of the following nerve is being tested:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the soft palate, and its movements are controlled by the vagus nerve (CN X). The vagus nerve innervates the muscles of the soft palate and plays a crucial role in swallowing and speech.

Other options:

B. Facial (CN VII): The facial nerve innervates the muscles of facial expression and is not involved in controlling the movements of the soft palate.

C. Glossopharyngeal (CN IX): The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue and the oropharynx and does not control the movements of the soft palate.

D. Trigeminal (CN V): The trigeminal nerve supplies sensory innervation to the face and controls the muscles of mastication but is not involved in controlling the movements of the soft palate.
